questions.text: Which of the following structures do not pass through both greater and lesser sciatic foramens?
questions.solution:
The tendon of the obturator internus muscle passes only through the lesser sciatic foramen.

Structures passing through both the greater and lesser sciatic foramen:

  • Pudendal nerve
  • Internal pudendal vessels
  • Nerve to obturator internus.

Related Pearl: Structures Passing Through the Sciatic Foramens

Structures passing through the greater sciatic foramen

The piriformis is the key muscle of this region. It emerges from the pelvis, and fills the foramen almost completely.

Structures passing above the piriformis

  • Superior gluteal nerve
  • Superior gluteal vessels

Structures passing below the piriformis

  • Inferior gluteal nerve         
  • Inferior gluteal vessels
  • Sciatic nerve                                              
  • Posterior cutaneous nerve of thigh
  • Nerve to quadratus femoris                  
  • Pudendal nerve
  • Internal pudendal vessels                                  
  • Nerve to obturator internus

Note: The last three structures, after a short course in the gluteal region, enter the lesser sciatic foramen, where the pudendal nerve and internal pudendal vessels run in the pudendal canal.

Structures passing through the lesser sciatic foramen

  • Tendon of obturator internus
  • Pudendal nerve
  • Internal pudendal vessels
  • Nerve to obturator internus

questions.text: All of the following structures are derived from the aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle except:
questions.solution:
Linea semilunaris is derived from the aponeurosis of the internal oblique muscle.

Pectineal ligament, inguinal ligament and lacunar ligament are derived from the external oblique aponeurosis.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles does not form the floor of the femoral triangle?
questions.solution:
Psoas major forms the floor of the femoral triangle, not psoas minor.

The femoral triangle is an intermuscular space in the anteromedial aspect of the thigh. Its boundaries are:

  • Lateral boundary is formed by the medial margin of sartorius 
  • Medial boundary is formed by the medial margin of adductor longus.
  • Floor of the femoral triangle from lateral to medial is formed by:
    • Iliacus
    • Psoas major 
    • Pectineus
    • Adductor longus

questions.text: Which of the following forms the lateral boundary of the femoral triangle?
questions.solution:
The lateral boundary of the femoral triangle is formed by the medial margin of the sartorius.

Its medial boundary is formed by the medial margin of adductor longus.

Related Pearl: Femoral Triangle

The femoral triangle is a depressed, intermuscular space present in the anteromedial aspect of the proximal thigh.

Boundaries of Femoral triangle are:

Medially- Medial border of Adductor longus

Laterally- Medial border of Sartorius

Base- Inguinal ligament

Floor (lateral to medial)- Iliacus, Psoas major, Pectineus, Adductor longus

Roof- Skin, Superficial fascia, Fascia lata, superficial branches of femoral vessels–superficial epigastric, superficial external pudendal, superficial circumflex iliac vessels and GSV. 

Note: Femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve which forms a content of the triangle also forms its roof as it pierces the fascia to supply the skin over the triangle. 

Contents:

  • Femoral sheath containing lymph node of Cloquet, femoral vein, femoral artery, femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve.
  • Femoral nerve and its branches
  • Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve of thigh

questions.text: A resident was inserting a central venous line through the femoral vein. He accidentally injured the structure medial to the femoral vein, within the femoral sheath. Which structure is likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
The lymphatic vessels lie medial to the femoral vein and are likely to be injured in this case.

Femoral sheath is the funnel-shaped prolongation of the fascia which contains femoral vessels. Anteriorly it is made of transversalis fascia and posteriorly it is made of fascia iliaca.

It is divided into three compartments:

  • The lateral compartment contains femoral artery
  • The intermediate compartment contains femoral vein
  • The medial compartment which is termed as femoral canal contains:
    • Lymphatic vessels
    • Areolar tissue
    • Lymph node of Cloquet. 

The empty space in the femoral canal allows distension of the adjacent femoral vein, so it can cope with increased venous return, or increased intra-abdominal pressure.

questions.text: A patient underwent an aortic valve replacement surgery through the femoral artery. Post-operatively, he complaints of groin pain radiating down the anteromedial thigh. Which of the following is true regarding the nerve injured?

choices.text: It lies medial to the femoral artery
It is not a content of the femoral sheath
The nerve injured is the sciatic nerve
It arises from the anterior cords of the lumbar plexus

questions.solution:
The nerve injured is the femoral nerve. Femoral nerve is not a content of the femoral sheath. 

Femoral sheath forms a fascial compartment which is further divided into 3 compartments by the intervening septae:

  • The lateral compartment contains femoral artery
  • The intermediate compartment contains femoral vein
  • The medial compartment which is termed as femoral canal contains 
    • Lymphatic vessels
    • Areolar tissue
    • Lymph node of cloquet

The empty space in the femoral canal allows distension of the adjacent femoral vein, so it can cope with increased venous return, or increased intra-abdominal pressure.

Option A - Femoral nerve lies lateral to the femoral artery

Option C - Sciatic nerve injury may occur after misplaced intramuscular injection in the gluteal region. It leads to loss of sensation at the outer side of ankle and heel and foot drop.

questions.text: A middle aged man is found to have a globular swelling below and lateral to the pubic tubercle. A diagnosis of femoral hernia is made. Which structure forms the posterior border of the ring the hernia passes through?
questions.solution:
Femoral hernia will pass through the femoral ring proximally. The posterior border of the femoral ring is formed by the pectineal ligament.

Relations of the femoral ring:

  • Anterior border by the inguinal ligament
  • Posterior border by the
    • Pectineal ligament
    • Superior ramus of the pubic bone
    • Pectineus muscle
  • Medial border by the lacunar ligament
  • Lateral border by the femoral vein

questions.text: An adolescent is crossing the road while playing loud music on his headphones. He is struck by a car and rushed to the emergency room. The physicians notice a distal femur fracture with vascular compromise.  Intraoperatively, the femoral vessels are found to be injured at the adductor hiatus. Which muscle is likely to be involved in this injury ?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, femoral vessels are injured at the adductor hiatus. The adductor hiatus is an opening in the tendon of the adductor magnus. Hence, the muscle likely to be injured is the adductor magnus.

Clinical relevance: The adductor part of the adductor magnus attaches to the distal femur. Distal femur fractures may cause femoral artery injury and impairment of the blood supply to the lower leg.

questions.text: The hunter's canal lies beneath which muscle?
questions.solution:
The hunter’s canal lies beneath the sartorius muscle. It is also referred to as the subsartorial canal or adductor canal.

The hunter’s canal is a triangular intermuscular tunnel occupying the lower two-thirds of the medial aspect of the thigh.

Related Pearl: Adductor Canal

           Boundaries of Adductor Canal
Antero-lateral wall Vastus medialis
Postero-medial wall (Floor)

Adductor longus (above),

Adductor magnus (below)
Medial wall(Roof)

Fibrous band connecting vastus medialis with adductor longus(Subsartorial fascia)

Sartorius

Subsartorial nerve plexus
Contents

Femoral artery

Femoral vein

Saphenous nerve

Nerve to vastus medialis

Descending genicular artery 

Deep lymph vessels

Two terminal divisions of the obturator nerve

questions.text: A 40 year old basketball player who sustained an ACL tear is being posted for ACL reconstruction surgery. The anesthetist plans an adductor canal block for the procedure. Which of the following structures is he least likely to encounter while giving the block ?
questions.solution:
The femoral nerve is least likely to be encountered while giving an adductor canal block. Adductor canal does not contain the femoral nerve. However, it contains its branches - the saphenous and and nerve to vastus medialis.

Contents of the adductor canal:

  • Saphenous nerve (largest cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve)
  • Nerve to vastus medialis 
  • Femoral artery
  • Descending genicular artery
  • Femoral vein
  • Deep lymphatic vessels 

Related Pearl: Adductor Canal

           Boundaries of Adductor Canal
Antero-lateral wall Vastus medialis
Postero-medial wall (Floor)

Adductor longus (above),

Adductor magnus (below)
Medial wall(Roof)

Fibrous band connecting vastus medialis with adductor longus(Subsartorial fascia)

Sartorius

Subsartorial nerve plexus
Contents

Femoral artery

Femoral vein

Saphenous nerve

Nerve to vastus medialis

Descending genicular artery 

Deep lymph vessels

Two terminal divisions of the obturator nerve

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct relationship with regards to the saphenous nerve in the adductor canal?
questions.solution:
The saphenous nerve is anterior to the femoral artery in the adductor canal.

Related Pearl: Adductor Canal

           Boundaries of Adductor Canal
Antero-lateral wall Vastus medialis
Postero-medial wall (Floor)

Adductor longus (above),

Adductor magnus (below)
Medial wall(Roof)

Fibrous band connecting vastus medialis with adductor longus(Subsartorial fascia)

Sartorius

Subsartorial nerve plexus
Contents

Femoral artery

Femoral vein

Saphenous nerve

Nerve to vastus medialis

Descending genicular artery 

Deep lymph vessels

Two terminal divisions of the obturator nerve

questions.text: A patient presents with a chronic ulcer in the popliteal fossa. The surgeon plans to make a musculocutaneous flap using a muscle from the superolateral boundary of the fossa. Which muscle is to be used for the flap?
questions.solution:
The surgeon plans to use the biceps femoris muscle for the flap.
Biceps femoris forms the superolateral border of the popliteal fossa.

Popliteal fossa is a diamond-shaped region present posterior to the knee.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a content of the popliteal fossa?
questions.solution:
The lateral femoral cutaneous nerve is not a content of the popliteal fossa. It arises from the ventral rami of L2 and L3, and ends up supplying the skin of anterolateral thigh.

Contents of Popliteal fossa:

  • Popliteal artery and its branches
  • Popliteal vein and its tributaries
  • Tibial nerve
  • Common fibular (Peroneal) nerve
  • Short saphenous vein
  • Posterior femoral cutaneous nerve
  • Articular branch of the obturator nerve
  • Medial and Lateral sural cutaneous nerve
  • Lymph nodes
  • Fat
  • Bursae

questions.text: Which of the following bones form the anterior pillar of the lateral longitudinal arch of the foot?

choices.text: Talus, navicular, 3 cuneiform and 1st, 2nd and 3rd metatarsal

questions.solution:
The anterior pillar of the lateral longitudinal arch of the foot is formed by 4th and 5th metatarsals.

Related Pearl: Comparative features of the medial and lateral longitudinal arches of the foot.

Features

Medial Longitudinal arch

Lateral longitudinal arch

Anterior pillar

Talus, navicular, 3 cuneiform and 1st, 2nd and 3rd metatarsal

Cuboid and 4th, 5th metatarsals

Posterior pillar

Medial half of calcaneum

Lateral half of calcaneum

Main joint involved

Talo calcaneonavicular joint (TCN)

Calcaneocuboid joint

Summit

Superior articular surface of Talus

Superior articular surface of Calcaneum (at the leveled Subtalar joint)

Extremities (piers)

Tuberosity of calcaneum posteriorly and Heads of 1st, 2nd, 3rd metatarsal anteriorly

Plantar surface of calcaneum posteriorly and Heads of 4th, 5th metatarsals anteriorly

Ligament/intersegmental ties

Plantar calcaneonavicular ligament (spring ligament)

Long and short plantar ligaments

Tie beams

Plantar aponeurosis (medial part)

Abductor hallucis

Medial part of  flexor digitorum brevis

Plantar aponeurosis (lateral part)

Abductor digiti minimi

Slings

Tibialis anterior 

Tibialis posterior

Flexor hallucis longus

Flexor digitorum longus

 

Peroneus longus

Peroneus brevis

questions.text: The keystone of the medial longitudinal arch is formed by ______.
questions.solution:
The keystone (summit) of the medial longitudinal arch is formed by the talus.

Related Pearl: Comparative features of the medial and lateral longitudinal arches of the foot.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man had trauma to the right foot, following which he complained of difficulty in walking. Examination showed collapse of the medial longitudinal arch. Injury to all of the following structures may cause the given condition except:
questions.solution:
Peroneus longus muscle maintains the lateral longitudinal arch and not the medial arch.

The muscles, tendons, and aponeurosis that maintain the longitudinal arches of the foot are of two types:

  • Slings: These structures help to maintain the arch by suspending the arch from above.
  • Tie beams (bowstrings): These are present between the anterior and posterior pillars and help maintain the arch by preventing the separation of the pillars.

Related Pearl: Comparative features of the medial and lateral longitudinal arches of the foot.

Features

Medial Longitudinal arch

Lateral longitudinal arch

Anterior pillar

Talus, navicular, 3 cuneiform and 1st, 2nd and 3rd metatarsal

Cuboid and 4th, 5th metatarsals

Posterior pillar

Medial half of calcaneum

Lateral half of calcaneum

Main joint involved

Talo calcaneonavicular joint (TCN)

Calcaneocuboid joint

Summit

Superior articular surface of Talus

Superior articular surface of Calcaneum (at the leveled Subtalar joint)

Extremities (piers)

Tuberosity of calcaneum posteriorly and Heads of 1st, 2nd, 3rd metatarsal anteriorly

Plantar surface of calcaneum posteriorly and Heads of 4th, 5th metatarsals anteriorly

questions.text: Which of the following structures does not pass deep to the superior extensor retinacula of foot?
questions.solution:
The tendon of tibialis posterior does not pass deep to the superior extensor retinacula of the foot. 

The following are the structures passing deep to the superior and inferior extensor retinacula:

  • Tibialis anterior tendon
  • Extensor hallucis longus tendon
  • Deep peroneal nerve
  • Extensor digitorum longus tendon
  • Peroneus tertius tendon

The anterior tibial vessels pass deep to the superior extensor retinaculum, while the dorsalis pedis vessels pass deep to the inferior extensor retinaculum.

Note: The tendon of tibialis posterior passes deep to the flexor retinaculum of the foot

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the inferior extensor retinaculum of the foot?

choices.text: The upper band is attached to the lower end of the fibula
The lower band is attached to the deep fascia of sole
Laterally it is attached to calcaneum

questions.solution:
Upper band is attached to medial malleolus of the tibia and not fibula.

Inferior extensor retinaculum:

  • It is a Y-shaped band lying anterior to the ankle joint.
  • The stem of the Y is at the lateral end and is attached to the upper surface of the calcaneus.
  • The limbs of the Y are at the medial end. The proximal limb attaches to the medial malleolus and the distal limb blends with the plantar aponeurosis.

Structures passing deep to retinaculum are:

  • Peroneus tertius
  • Extensor digitorum longus
  • Extensor hallucis longus
  • Tibialis anterior
  • Anterior tibial vessels
  • Dorsalis pedis artery
  • Deep peroneal nerve

questions.text: Which of the following is the most medial structure passing through the canals in the flexor retinaculum of the foot?
questions.solution:
Tibialis posterior tendon is the most medial structure passing through the canals in the flexor retinaculum of the foot.

The flexor retinaculum of the foot converts grooves on the tibia and calcaneus into canals for the tendons. The structures passing through canals formed by flexor retinaculum are as follows: (from medial to lateral)

  • Tendons of tibialis posterior
  • Flexor digitorum longus
  • The posterior tibial vessels
  • The tibial nerve
  • The tendon of flexor hallucis longus
